channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: Obama Hands Venezuelan Leader a Cause to Stir Support
item.description: Washington’s hope that freezing assets of Venezuelan officials would focus attention on deteriorating conditions may have given President Nicolás Maduro momentum to crack down on his opposition.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela. The United States has formally declared his country an “extraordinary threat.’’

item.title: Delhi to Delay Release of Air Quality Data
item.description: Some analysts accused the government of trying to hide data that show the city’s air to be the world’s most toxic.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Smoke rising from burning garbage in New Delhi last year. The city’s air is the world’s most toxic, according to global rankings.

item.title: Frei Otto, Architect, Dies at 89; the Soap Bubble Was an Inspiration
item.description: A lack of construction materials after World War II forced Mr. Otto to innovate; he created dazzling tensile structures while minimizing the use of material.
item.dc:creator: FRED A. BERNSTEIN
item.media:description: Frei Otto, in an undated photo, will be awarded the Pritzker Prize.

item.title: China’s Tensions With Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife
item.description: A comment by the Tibetan spiritual leader that he might not reincarnate has run afoul of the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Disenchanted by Civilian Life, Veterans Volunteer to Fight ISIS
item.description: A small number of Americans have offered to take up arms against the Islamic State, working with local militias in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS and THOMAS JAMES BRENNAN
item.media:description: Patrick Maxwell, right, with Sheikh Jaafar Mustafa, center, the former Kurdish regional government minister responsible for the pesh merga, and Dillon Hillier, a Canadian veteran who served in Afghanistan.

item.title: Kerry Criticizes Republican Letter to Iranian Leaders on Nuclear Talks
item.description: Testifying before the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, Secretary of State John Kerry said the letter might embolden Iranian hard-liners.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Family of Palestinian Man Killed by ISIS Says He Wasn’t Spying for Israel
item.description: Mohamed Musallam was seen in a video being shot in the head after the Islamic State claimed he had been sent to Syria to gather information on the group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: The parents of Mohamed Musallam mourned on Tuesday after the Islamic State released a video purportedly showing his killing.

item.title: Ebola Outbreak Could Be Ended by Summer, U.N. Says
item.description: Dr. Bruce Aylward said the crisis could be stopped completely, but only if funding continues and health workers can build trust in wary communities.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing: Armed Thieves in France Steal Jewels Worth Millions
item.description: About 15 heavily armed thieves attacked two armored vans carrying jewels overnight on a highway connecting Paris and Lyon, stealing gems valued at about $9.7 million, the police said.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Italian Court Upholds Berlusconi’s Acquittal in Sex Case
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, had been accused of paying for sex with an underage prostitute in what had become known as the “bunga bunga” case.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, center, outside his Rome residence, Palazzo Grazioli, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. to Give Ukraine’s Military an Additional $75 Million in Nonlethal Aid
item.description: The Obama administration also imposed sanctions against a handful of pro-Russian separatists and others blamed for fomenting the civil war that has torn apart Ukraine’s eastern regions.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Fans Call for Return of ‘Top Gear’ Host Suspended by BBC
item.description: Thousands signed an online petition seeking the reinstatement of Jeremy Clarkson, who was suspended after a “fracas” with a producer.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Jeremy Clarkson, who was suspended as a host of the BBC program "Top Gear," in London on Wednesday.

item.title: At War Blog: The Curious Draw of the Battlefield
item.description: A former Marine reflects on the news that another former Marine, Patrick Maxwell, volunteered in northern Iraq to fight Islamic State militants.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THOMAS JAMES BRENNAN

item.title: In Tidjane Thiam, Credit Suisse Gets Risk Expertise
item.description: Mr. Thiam was chosen to lead a company that has done poorly after emerging from a scandal.
item.dc:creator: JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: Brady W. Dougan, the exiting chief of Credit Suisse, left, with Tidjane Thiam, his designated successor, at a news conference on Tuesday in Zurich.

item.title: With Plan to Walk Across DMZ, Women Aim for Peace in Korea
item.description: Leading female advocates of disarmament formally announced their intent to cross the Demilitarized Zone, which has divided the Korean Peninsula since 1953.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers stood guard in the village of Panmunjom on the border with North Korea last month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Tensions With Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife
item.description: A comment by the Tibetan spiritual leader that he might not reincarnate has run afoul of the Communist Party, which said he must, and that the party was the proper guardian of his succession.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A Tibetan at a refugee camp in Lalitpur, Nepal, with a portrait of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader.

item.title: Suspect in Nemtsov Killing Was Most Likely Forced to Confess, Rights Activist Says
item.description: A member of the Kremlin’s advisory council on human rights said three of the suspects arrested after the death of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov had suffered injuries in captivity.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Zaur Dadayev, whom the Russian authorities say is the main suspect in the shooting death of Boris Y. Nemtsov, was escorted by the police from a courtroom in Moscow last week.

item.title: Pritzker Prize for Frei Otto, German Architect, Is Announced After His Death
item.description: Mr. Otto was recognized for his airy tentlike structures and other inventive feats of engineering.
item.dc:creator: ROBIN POGREBIN
item.media:description: Mr. Otto's stadium roof canopies for the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich were widely admired for their lightness and strength.

item.title: ISIS Attacks Ramadi as Iraqi Army Takes Ground in Tikrit
item.description: Militant fighters of the Islamic State set off 21 car bombs in the city of Ramadi but lost ground to an Iraqi government offensive in Tikrit, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Militiamen during an operation on Wednesday to take control of Tikrit, Iraq, from the Islamic State.

item.title: News Analysis: Politics and Tradition Collide Over Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Even as Republicans emphasized the limits of a deal brokered by a president without submitting it to Congress, White House allies fumed about their interference in delicate negotiations.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and STEVEN ERLANGER
